results.justification: The document clearly states the research aims and overall approach to evaluating the LA hint system.
Sections 3.1-3.4 provide a detailed description of the virtual PBL environment, participants, LA hint system, and data sources, outlining the experimental design.
The document does not mention any publicly available datasets or provide a link to where they can be found. There is no justification for why the data cannot be shared.
Tables 1, 2, and 3 serve as codebooks explaining the mapping of raw logs to PBL steps and the coding scheme for student statements. Section 3.4.2 describes the scale used for measuring self-efficacy.
Data collection methods are fully described in section 3.4, including details on problem-solving performance scores, self-efficacy scales, student interviews, and student-generated log data.
The document does not mention any shared code repository (e.g., GitHub, GitLab).
Since no code is shared, there are no scripts for data cleaning, analysis, or visualization.
Statistical tests (ANOVA, ANCOVA) are clearly described, and effect sizes, confidence intervals, and p-values are reported (e.g., 'F(3,285) = 4.54, p < .05').

The document describes the coding process for student interviews (guided by Miles et al.'s framework) and states that 100% inter-rater reliability was achieved. Subjective context and interpretation are provided throughout the results section.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration.
The document clearly presents the results of the study, including the effects of the LA hint system on problem-solving performance and self-efficacy.
Section 5.3 discusses implications for future practice and acknowledges potential biases, such as the impact of teacher reminders on the static hint system condition.
